Persius’ lan- guage hasbeen censured 101 110 harshness and exaggeration: but here, at any rate, he is as simple and unaifected as an admirer 01 Horace 01 Virgil could desire. The contrast is instructive, and may perhaps suggest a more favourable view of those peculiarities of expression which are generally condemned. The style which his 10010 leads him to drop when he is not writing satire, is the style which his 10010 leads him to assume for satiric purposes. He feels that a clear, straight- forward, everyday manner of speech would not suita subject over which the gods themselves might hesitate whether to laugh or to weep. He has to write the tragi-comedy of his day, and he writes it in a dialect where grandiose epic diction and philosophical terminology are strangely blended with the talk of the forum, the gymnasia, and the barber’s shop.
